Good evening staff and community members,

Yesterday afternoon the company installing the shade structures and solar panels at Dos Palos Elementary (DPE) hit an underground fuel tank. This fuel tank has been under the ground and unused for nearly 60 years, dating back to when DPE was a transportation location for the elementary school district.

The solar company has stopped construction at DPE and the district has contacted the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The EPA (along with other governmental agencies) will provide guidance to the district on the next steps to remove the fuel tank and excavate the dirt around the tank.
This issue was unforeseen, but the district is committed to ensuring all students and staff will return to a safe school environment. The safety of students and staff is our number one priority.

Beginning, Monday, April 6, teachers and school staff will call parents regarding your child's access to computers and internet at home. If you have any questions, please contact your child's school. Our educators are working hard to provide for distance learning opportunities for every student we serve.

Also, as a reminder there will be no meal service during the Spring Break (April 10-17). Meal service will resume beginning, Monday, April 20.

Sincerely,
Justin Miller, Ed.D

Andrea Valtierra-Gongora from the Merced County District Attorney's Office presented information to parents about the importance of student attendance today. The event was put on by Mr. Frank Lemos (SARB Coordinator) as a proactive approach to inform and educate parents.

Student attendance directly affects student achievement and future success into adulthood. As a district, we understand the value of student attendance and want what is best for all students. We encourage all parents to work with school staff to ensure all students regularly attend school.

*A student who misses 10 days or more during a school year is 20% less likely to graduate from high school and 25% less likely to ever enroll in college.
